tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
"people should play stringed instruments with this song"
This may refer to a style of music.
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.
The bones represent the whole body. His body may have been shaking because he was sick or extremely tired. AT: "my whole body is shaking" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"terrified" or "worried"
David uses this question to show that he does not want to continue feeling weak and troubled. AT: please, do not let this continue!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
David speaks of God being kind to him as God returning to him. AT: "Yahweh, come back to me" or "Have mercy on me, Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: For in death there is no remembrance of you. In Sheol who will give you thanks?
tn.text: These two sentences express similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: For in death there is no remembrance of you
tn.text: Remembrance represents praise. AT: "For when people die, they no longer praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: In Sheol who will give you thanks?
tn.text: David uses this question to emphasize that no one in Sheol thanks God. AT: "No one in Sheol will give you thanks!" or "The dead cannot praise you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: I am weary with my groaning
tn.text: His groaning represents the pain or distress that he feels. AT: "I am very tired because of my pain" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I drench my bed with tears; I wash my couch away with my tears
tn.text: These two sentences express the same meaning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: I drench my bed with tears
tn.text: "I make my bed wet with my tears" or "My bed is very wet because of my tears"

tn.ref: I wash my couch away with my tears
tn.text: "I make my couch wet with my tears"
The ability to see is spoken of in terms of the eyes. AT: "My vision is blurry" or  "I cannot see clearly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Grief here represents crying. AT: "from crying" or "because I cry so much" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Yahweh has heard my appeal for mercy ... Yahweh has accepted my prayer
tn.text: These two lines have very similar meanings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Being willing to do what David has prayed for is spoken of as accepting his prayer.  AT: "Yahweh will respond to my prayer" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
